image.altText: A composite of images of a young and old Mick Doleman and a shipwreck under the ocean.

items.synopsis: The wreck of the Blythe Star is located almost 50 years after it sank off the Tasmanian coast, its crew believed dead — until, astonishingly, they appeared out of the bush far from where the ship sank.

title.children: The crew of the Blythe Star were thought lost at sea. So why did they stumble out of a forest?

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff clutching an AFL football.

items.synopsis: A disgruntled former Tasmanian Liberal MP who quit the party over the stadium project says she will only support next week's budget if stadium funding is clearly identified.

title.children: 'I believe in this project': Premier vows he won't back down on Hobart AFL stadium

image.altText: Lara Alexander wears a black coat and blue and pink scarf and stands on a suburban Launceston street

items.synopsis: Newly independent MP Lara Alexander says a "huge weight" has been lifted from her shoulders, while the Tasmanian Greens' push to axe Hobart's new stadium look set for failure without Labor's support.

title.children: Newly independent MP Lara Alexander says Rockliff 'only has himself to blame'

image.altText: A sign shows a red scull and bones and reads "contaminated".

items.synopsis: The Commonwealth has stopped short of admitting liability in a class action settlement that will see  $132.7 million split among 30,000 claimants who have suffered from toxic PFAS contamination from firefighting foam.

title.children: 30,000 claimants to share $132.7m payout after Commonwealth settles PFAS class action

image.altText: Jasmina, woman in pink shirt smiling, holding a baby wearing a blue shirt.

items.synopsis: Michelle and Jono Harley always dreamed of having a family — their devastating fertility journey took a twist when relatives stepped in with an extraordinary backup plan.

title.children: Jasmina was 52 when she gave birth to her grandson. Now her daughter has her dream family

image.altText: Female doctor wearing blue top and jacket in an office. Her hair is close-cropped and she wears glasses.

items.synopsis: Celebrity endorsements and social media influencers are helping drive more women to freeze their eggs. But one doctor is warning young women to seriously consider the financial, physical and emotional toll.

title.children: This doctor warns women not to 'jump into' egg freezing

image.altText: A young girl smiles while looking up towards the camera wearing a backpack.

items.synopsis: The mother of Cleo Smith, Ellie Smith, says her family remains angry and heartbroken after the sentencing of the man who snatched her five-year-old daughter from a remote WA campsite.

title.children: 'Someone's tied our child, someone's hurt our kid': Family of Cleo Smith still angry over 'disgusting' kidnapping

image.altText: A dog sits in a dog carrier on a Harley Davidson, there is a bike trailer attached. All black bike, brown dog

items.synopsis: Six years on from adopting a little dog in Tasmania, Andrew Darwood has travelled most of Australia with his mate, Tassie, sitting at his back on a motorcycle.

title.children: Tassie the dog has chewed up 20,000km on motorcycle road trips, and can't wait for the next one

image.altText: people standing outside an apartment block waiting to view it as a rent sign stands on the footpath

items.synopsis: The tax office says it is cracking down on landlords who are over-claiming tax deductions.

title.children: Tax Office's warning on landlord deductions, capital gains tax risk for Airbnb operators

image.altText: A woman and a man near Ayers Rock in Northern territory.

items.synopsis: Julie Schutt, who was missing in regional South Australia for a week, had not had any food or water in all the time she was missing, her brother says.

title.children: 'She was on her last legs': Missing Queensland woman was making way to a farmhouse when she was found

image.altText: Online scam

items.synopsis: A national anti-scams centre is being established to help combat scams and online fraud, after Australians reported losing billions of dollars to fraudsters last year.

title.children: Government reveals details of $58m anti-scams centre, with expert 'hit squads' targeting fraudsters

image.altText: The first man has a tattoos on his face, the middle dark hair and beard, the third has receding dark hair & a moustache.

items.synopsis: A major manhunt is underway for a man who disappeared from the rural, low-security Palen Creek Correctional Centre with two other men yesterday afternoon.

title.children: 'Do not approach them': Police capture two men after trio escape Queensland prison

image.altText: A man wearing a suit looks at the camera

items.synopsis: Bruce Lehrmann's defence barrister Steve Whybrow tells an inquiry into the case that he was angered by the suggestion he colluded with Senator Linda Reynolds during the trial.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's barrister 'pissed off' over prosecutor's claims he colluded with Linda Reynolds during trial

image.altText: An older white man in heavily armoured combat gear and a helmet stands on a rooftop, with a soldier looking out behind him.

items.synopsis: Today, as Russia's President Vladimir Putin flails around dispatching one failed military chief after another, Yevgeny Prigozhin — for the moment at least — is probably the safest Russian in the world, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: Putin needs this man more than anyone else — until the moment he ceases to be of use

image.altText: Sam Kerr squats behind the Women's FA Cup while holding the Australian flag and wearing her Chelsea jersey.

items.synopsis: The Matildas captain scores in Chelsea's 1-0 win over Manchester United, making her the outright most successful Australian footballer ever.

title.children: In a game of big moments, Sam Kerr's small glories set her apart

image.altText: Two sawfish lie dead on a sandy bank with their saws, also known as rostrums, cut off.

items.synopsis: An aquatic ecosystems expert at Murdoch University compares the "illegal" and "cruel" killing of four fish to poaching rhinos and elephants for their ivory.

title.children: Critically endangered sawfish likely killed for saw trophies, marine professor says

image.altText: River height markers in flood

items.synopsis: The money will be spent upgrading thousands of faulty or outdated flood gauges, which have left communities unprepared during natural disasters.

title.children: $263m to be spent on upgrading flood gauges 'a matter of saving lives'

image.altText: Dominic Savage, Mia Threapleton and Kate Winslet pose while holding BAFTA awards. Threapleton and WInslet share a glance.

items.synopsis: Derry Girls, Bad Sisters, The Traitors and Paddington are among the big winners at the BAFTA TV Awards in London.

title.children: Kate Winslet wins big, alongside Queen Elizabeth II and Paddington at the BAFTA TV awards

image.altText: A woman smiling and holding a baby at a cafe

items.synopsis: Lawyers for a man charged over the alleged murder of Louise Hughes, who was found dead at a house in Adelaide's south-west, are calling for the charges to be dropped after an autopsy report showed inconclusive results.

title.children: Lawyers call for murder charges to be dropped after inconclusive autopsy report

image.altText: A grey card with the PTV and myki symbols is placed against a card reader which says the card has expired.

items.synopsis: It's the end of the line for many physical myki cards, with Victorian commuters to be able to pay for public transport with their debit and credit cards in trials starting in 2024.

title.children: Physical myki cards to tap out as Victoria gives ticketing contract to new company

image.altText: Jason Day hugs his son as he walks off a golf course in the rain.

items.synopsis: Thirteen years after winning his maiden PGA Tour crown at the Byron Nelson, Australian Jason Day wins the Texas event again for his first victory since 2018 and 13th overall.

title.children: Jason Day ends five-year title drought at the site of his maiden triumph

image.altText: Tom and Greg look at something out of frame with concern as they sit at a conference table with writing on a board behind them.

items.synopsis: It's election night! The polls have closed, the touchscreen is ready, but the Roys can't decide on who should be the next president. They might just destroy democracy in the process.

title.children: Succession recap: The Roys decide America's future. What could go wrong?

image.altText: An island in the distance across the water

items.synopsis: An air and sea search continues for a man still missing after authorities received a distress call from a yacht off Sandy Cape last night.

title.children: Woman rescued, man still missing off K'gari (Fraser Island)

image.altText: A woman lights a flare standing next to a car

items.synopsis: Türkiye appears headed for a run-off presidential election, with the parties of both Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and opposition rival Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu both failing to secure 50 per cent of the vote.

title.children: Türkiye's presidential candidates fail to secure 50 per cent of the vote in crucial elections

image.altText: Children play next to adults at a park in Beijing, China

items.synopsis: Pilot projects will be launched in more than 20 Chinese cities to encourage women to marry and have children, the latest move by authorities to boost the country's falling birth rate.

title.children: China launches projects to build 'new-era' marriage and child-bearing culture

image.altText: Singer Kelly Clarkson poses for a portrait on the set of The Kelly Clarkson Show

items.synopsis: Singer and television personality Kelly Clarkson is at the forefront of a Rolling Stone report from early May that accused her self-titled talk show of being a toxic workplace.

title.children: Kelly Clarkson addresses allegations of a 'toxic workplace' on her talk show

image.altText: Person leaning over a table wearing a hooded gown, with a box of tissues and a mug on the table.

items.synopsis: This respiratory virus is so common that most children will have had at least one infection before they turn two. Most cases are mild, but it can cause severe illness for young children, the elderly and the immunocompromised.

title.children: Australia has been counting RSV cases for less than two years. Here are the basics about the common cold virus

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The ASX is flat as two big banks trade without rights to their latest dividend payments. NAB tips at least one more interest rate rise. Follow the day's financial news and insights from our specialist business reporters on our live blog.

title.children: ASX flat as two big banks go ex-dividend, NAB tips at least one more interest rate rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not a dead certainty yet, but TPG's upwardly revised bid has won over the board of funeral operator Invocare. The private equity firm looks set to have one foot in the grave, after Invocare's board indicated its support for the $13.00 a share bid, inclusive of a fully-franked dividend of up to 60 cents a share that could yield tax benefits for many shareholders. The latest offer is a 45% premium to Invocare's share price immediately prior to the initial bid, but it's a relatively small increase on the initial $12.65 a share offer that was rebuffed. The new offer has prompted Invocare to open up its books for TPG to do due diligence, but there's no guarantee a binding bid will arrive if the private equity firm finds any financial skeletons in the closet. If it does go ahead the deal gives Invocare an enterprise value of $2.2 billion showing the business of death is in rude health.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Invocare will accept upwardly revised private equity bid

children.content: It's not a dead certainty yet, but TPG's upwardly revised bid has won over the board of funeral operator Invocare.
The private equity firm looks set to have one foot in the grave, after
Invocare's board indicated its support for the $13.00 a share bid
, inclusive of a fully-franked dividend of up to 60 cents a share that could yield tax benefits for many shareholders.
The latest offer is a 45% premium to Invocare's share price immediately prior to the initial bid, but it's a relatively small increase on the initial $12.65 a share offer that was rebuffed.
The new offer has prompted Invocare to open up its books for TPG to do due diligence
, but there's no guarantee a binding bid will arrive if the private equity firm finds any financial skeletons in the closet.
If it does go ahead the deal gives
Invocare an enterprise value of $2.2 billion
showing the business of death is in rude health.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ economists Brian Martin and Tom Kenny have put together a useful summary of the US debt ceiling debate and risks of default. They are a little more relaxed than Rabobank's global strategists, but only a little. Here are some highlights (or lowlights): "The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) projects that, if the debt limit remains unchanged, the government's ability to continue spending using extraordinary measures will be exhausted by early June. In that event, many government workers could not get paid, social security and other payments would be at risk and the Treasury would be unable to borrow. Recession risks would intensify sharply." Just how bad could it get? Very, according to recent forecasts. "The consequences of a default would be disastrous. " US Council of Economic Advisors (CEA) estimates a short default would cause a 0.3% rise in unemployment and 0.6% contraction in GDP. A protracted default would cause a 5.0% rise in unemployment and 6.1% fall in GDP. "A default would also provoke a sharp rise in yields and wreak havoc in all financial markets and the real economy in the US and internationally." So what do the ANZ economists think will happen? "We think the most likely scenarios are: 1. A longer-term agreement. We see a limited possibility (less than 10%) of a longer-term deal to lift or suspend the debt limit along the lines of the Republican bill. For now, the parties are too far apart and there is limited time in lawmakers' diaries to broker a deal before the X date. 2. A short-term compromise. We think a deal to suspend the debt limit by a few months is the most likely outcome (around 90%). This would be a similar outcome to what happened in October2021 when Democrats and Republicans agreed to increase the debt limit by USD480bn. This was said to be enough to provide funding till December 2021 or early January 2022. On 14 December 2021 the House and Senate passed a bill that saw the debt limit increased to its current level of USD31.4trn. 3. No agreement and the US defaults. According to the US Treasury this has never happened. Since 1960, Congress has acted 78 times to raise, temporarily extend or revise the definition of the debt limit. We think there is around a 1% chance of a default. A recent Chicago Fed paper claims Credit Default Swap (CDS) spreads data imply the probability of a default is 1%. This would likely be higher now, given that CDS spreads are a little higher compared to when the paper was published." So, the most likely outcome is another kick of the can down the road.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Debt ceiling debate approaches 11th hour' but ANZ confident US default will be avoided

children.content: ANZ economists Brian Martin and Tom Kenny
have put together a useful summary of the US debt ceiling debate and risks of default.
They are a little more relaxed than Rabobank's global strategists, but only a little.
Here are some highlights (or lowlights):
"The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) projects that, if the debt limit remains unchanged,
the government's ability to continue spending using extraordinary measures will be exhausted by early June
. In that event, many government workers could not get paid, social security and other payments would be at risk and the Treasury would be unable to borrow. Recession risks would intensify sharply."
Just how bad could it get? Very, according to recent forecasts.
"The consequences of a default would be disastrous.

US Council of Economic Advisors (CEA) estimates a short default would cause a 0.3% rise in unemployment and 0.6% contraction in GDP. A protracted default would cause a 5.0% rise in unemployment and 6.1% fall in GDP.
"A default would also provoke a sharp rise in yields and wreak havoc in all financial markets and the real economy in the US and internationally."
So what do the ANZ economists think will happen?
"We think the most likely scenarios are:
1. A longer-term agreement.
We see a limited possibility (less than 10%) of a longer-term deal to lift or suspend the debt limit along the lines of the Republican bill
. For now, the parties are too far apart and there is limited time in lawmakers' diaries to broker a deal before the X date.
2. A short-term compromise.
We think a deal to suspend the debt limit by a few months is the most likely outcome (around 90%).

This would be a similar outcome to what happened in October2021 when Democrats and Republicans agreed to increase the debt limit by USD480bn. This was said to be enough to provide funding till December 2021 or early January 2022. On 14 December 2021 the House and Senate passed a bill that saw the debt limit increased to its current level of USD31.4trn.

3. No agreement and the US defaults. According to the US Treasury this has never happened. Since 1960, Congress has acted 78 times to raise, temporarily extend or revise the definition of the debt limit.
We think there is around a 1% chance of a default.

A recent Chicago Fed paper claims Credit Default Swap (CDS) spreads data imply the probability of a default is 1%. This would likely be higher now, given that CDS spreads are a little higher compared to when the paper was published."
So, the most likely outcome is another kick of the can down the road.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm having strong deja vu vibes today, having also done the markets blog most of Friday. The market opened, fell slightly and continues to trade about 0.2% lower. The ASX 200 is on 7,241 points. Sound familiar? The only thing that could make it even more eerie is if it recovers late to finish slightly higher. The big drag on the market today are two ex-dividend big banks, ANZ and Macquarie, while NAB was the only major bank to trade higher. Resources companies are split. Take this example, gold miner Silver Lake Resources is one of the top gainers, up 7.4% to $1.09. Another company minus the "silver", Lake Resources (a lithium producer), is down 10% at $0.585. Despite its name, Silver Lake mines gold, and those producing the precious metal are generally trading strongly today, no doubt getting a boost from Newcrest's acceptance of a takeover by North American giant Newmont. Not only is that a sign of takeover interest in the sector that might spill over to other firms, but there is also talk that Newmont may want to split and sell-off some of Newcrest's non-core assets, potentially opening up buying opportunities. Rural services firm Elders was a notable mover, dropping 12.1%, or a dollar, to $7.30 after releasing its first-half profit results. No need to second guess what the market thought of its 42.4% slump in net profit to $48.8 million, which the company said was due to a "volatile" but also "more normalised" trading environment for agricultural commodities.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still pretty much where it started, as shares dip on ex-dividend banks

children.content: I'm having strong deja vu vibes today, having also done the markets blog most of Friday.
The market opened, fell slightly and continues to trade about 0.2% lower.
The ASX 200 is on 7,241 points
Sound familiar?

children.content: The market was also down 0.2% on Friday at 12:45pm AEST
(ABC News: Michael Janda)
The only thing that could make it even more eerie is if it recovers late to finish slightly higher.
The big drag on the market today are two ex-dividend big banks,
ANZ and Macquarie
, while
NAB
was the only major bank to trade higher.
Resources companies are split. Take this example, gold miner
Silver Lake Resources
is one of the top gainers, up 7.4% to $1.09. Another company minus the "silver",
Lake Resources
(a lithium producer), is down 10% at $0.585.
Despite its name, Silver Lake mines gold, and those producing the precious metal are generally trading strongly today, no doubt getting a boost from
Newcrest's acceptance of a takeover by North American giant Newmont

Not only is that a sign of takeover interest in the sector that might spill over to other firms, but there is also talk that Newmont may want to split and sell-off some of Newcrest's non-core assets, potentially opening up buying opportunities.
Rural services firm Elders
was a notable mover, dropping 12.1%, or a dollar, to $7.30 after
releasing its first-half profit results

No need to second guess what the market thought of its 42.4% slump in net profit to $48.8 million, which the company said was due to a "volatile" but also "more normalised" trading environment for agricultural commodities.

image.altText: Kevin Sinfield carries Rob Burrow over the line at the Leeds Marathon.

items.synopsis: Former England rugby league teammates Kevin Sinfield and Rob Burrow raise millions of pounds for research into motor neurone disease, after Burrow's diagnosis in 2019.

title.children: Kevin Sinfield carries former teammate Rob Burrow over marathon finish line, raising money to fight MND

image.altText: One of Saturn's rings is pictured with three differently sized half moons around it.

items.synopsis: Saturn has been recrowned "moon king" after scientists discovered 62 new moons in the gas planet's surroundings, using a technique called "shift and stack", bringing the total to 145, overtaking previous record holder Jupiter, which has a mere 95 recognised moons.

title.children: Saturn reclaims its title of 'moon king' with the discovery of 62 new moons orbiting the planet

image.altText: group of older men in bright shirts push wheelbarrow down main street of country town

items.synopsis: Raising funds for causes close to their hearts is just an added bonus for a team of military veterans who are part of a race that means a lot to the communities it visits.

title.children: Pushing 85 and pushing a wheelbarrow: Why veterans keep coming back for unique race
